Introduction
The quality and fitness for purpose of the healthcare estate and support services provided is vital for the delivery of high quality, safe and efficient healthcare.

The Estates & Facilities Management directorate (EFM) continually strive to work towards the delivery of high and safe standards of service at all times that meet legal and statutory requirements – this policy outlines the EFM management governance, regulatory and assurance framework.
In order assess a range of compliance and qualitative issues, each service must have key objectives with aligned performance indicators so that they can be measured accordingly.
There are multiple terms used for assessing and evaluating standards and compliance – for the purpose of this policy, the terms monitoring and audit will be used as the general term.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Purpose 1 - outline the evaluation and assurance framework for the EFM directorate including:
Evaluation against the CCQ fundamental standards, statutory and legal requirements
Monitoring and measuring the quality of standards and subsequent plans to improve
Embedment of good governance in the management model
Structure for reviewing, escalating and monitoring risks in accordance with Trust Risk Management Strategy and Health & Safety policies.
Purpose 2 - The main aims are to ensure that all services and deliverable outcomes within EFM directorate will:
Be compliant with statutory legislation and NHS regulatory requirements to ensure they are consistently monitored against with outcomes and actions clearly documented;
Have clear objectives with measurable performance indicators to test customer satisfaction, service standards and compliance with systems;
Have a process in place to escalate and act upon any standards fallen below standard or to be found non-compliant;
Enable, as a minimum, to aspire to a “good” rating in the Premises Assurance Model (PAM)
Maintain ISO standards in place including - ISO 9001-2015, ISO 14001-2015, ISO 45001-2018 and 13485:2016
Ensure risks and opportunities are recognised enabling mitigation or improvement plans to be continually reviewed and improved when assessed and planned and implemented or addressed when recognised.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committees and Groups

EFM Governance Board has responsibility for actively reviewing all policies and procedures and approving substantial changes or new policies and procedures. In addition the EFM Governance Board will be responsible for the monthly review of the EFM Risk Register, EFM performance, compliance and annual Management Review of Management Systems in accordance with ISO 9001, ISO 14001 and OHSAS 45001:2018.

EFM Efficiency Board  has responsibility for actively reviewing all policies and procedures and approving substantial changes or new policies and procedures. In addition the EFM Board will be responsible for the monthly review of the EFM Risk

EFM Site Groups has responsibility for actively reviewing performance reports and outcomes from EFM service audits and assessments, including review of new local risks prior to escalation to EFM Governance Board for approval.
Individual Roles

Senior Director of Estates & Facilities is the EFM directorate's Principle Engineer and accountable for the leadership and strategic management of the Estates and Facilities directorate to operate safely in providing non-clinical support services to the Trust as outlined in Appendix

Director of Specialist Services is responsible for the smooth delivery of specialist services which include space portfolio, sustainability, health safety, fire safety, compliance and specialist operational services including Medical Equipment and Sterile Services. This role is committed to the compliance against all relevant statutory, mandatory and national standards for health and safety for all Trust owned properties and assets.
Director of Operations is the responsible for the management and delivery of the operational services within the EFM directorate.
Health & Safety Management Group (HSMG) has responsibility to oversee safety audits and inspections, review outcomes and monitor action plans for scrutiny.

Head of Compliance is the focal point for assurance relating to compliance across all MSE sites and is responsible for the delivery of the annual PAM assessment and Compliance Programme and Action Tracker.
Head of Fire Safety is responsible for the delivery of the Fire Strategy, annual AE audit and annual reviews of fire safety risk assessments across the Trust.
Head of Health & Safety is responsible for the delivery of the Health & Safety Strategy, environmental inspections and annual reviews of environment risk assessments across the Trust.

Head of Business Development is responsible for Business Development Unit (BDU) which includes management of the directorate central core business and governance functions, including the audit and assurance programme, improvement and efficiency programme, performance reporting and facilitation of the BSI assessment programme against ISO standards for quality, health & safety an environment (excl. Quality Management standard for Sterile Services and Medical Equipment Management Services which ae management by the Head of Services).

Head of Sterile Services is responsible for facilitating the BSI quality management assessment relevant to Sterile Services only and also facilitating the BSI assessment of ISO 13485:2016 Medical Devices, Quality Management System.

Head of Medical Equipment Management Services (MEMS) is responsible for the management of MEMS across MSE and also facilitating the BSI assessment of ISO quality management assessment 9001:2015 (relevant to MEMS only).

Head of Sustainability will act as the Trust lead on Sustainable Development and Environmental Management ensuring compliance with the carbon management programme and any other environmental management requirements as well as ensuring cross-directorate and organisation wide engagement with the sustainability agenda.

Head of Estates Strategy and Planning has responsibility for the development of the long-term healthcare estates Masterplan and investment programme including the production of a five year strategic estates strategy, which facilitates the 5 year capital plan as the work book for capital project delivery. This role also has responsibility for assuring, driving, reporting and tracking the successful implementation of a multifaceted transformation programme of work and ensuring any associated business cases are driven by clinical demand, MSE organisational goals and alignment to wider objectives of the STP.
Head of Capital Projects Delivery has responsibility for the delivery of an extensive and complex programme of new and remodelled estates infrastructure reflecting the transformation strategy.

Head of Portfolio Management has responsibility for the optimisation of the changing Estates portfolio, ensuring property related legal and statutory due process through the creation of measured term contracts to improve management and monitoring of external contractors, ensuring standardisation of agreements, leases and licences to support the effective management of third part occupancies, leases and licence optimisation.. Development and implementation of a comprehensive estates information system which tracks utilisation and occupancy of the whole MSE estate and supports effective service planning for the group.

EFM Site Managers provide a strategic direction for the site based services which are filtered down from the overall EFM strategy and business improvement plans. They ensure that each service provides excellent quality services to patients with a cost effective approach. Managing the service contractors and ensuring they adhere to contractual agreement and the delivery of excellent service.
EFM Service Leads/Managers are responsible for ensuring that systems are in place to self-monitor standards of service in accordance with relevant statutory and NHS requirements.
Regulatory, statutory and mandatory requirements

There are a range of regulations and standard requirements that the EFM directorate must follow and strive to meet which include the following. Specific references to these are detailed within relevant EFM policies and procedures.
Care Quality Commission: the CQC's fundamental requirements with direct relevance to EFM operational standards and compliance include:
Regulation 14: Meeting nutrition and hydration needs – nutritional and
hydration needs of service users must be met
Regulation 15: Premises and equipment all premises and equipment used must be safe, clean, secure and suitable for the purpose for which they are being used, and properly used and maintained

Health & Safety Legislation: There is a wide range of legislation which places legal requirements on the NHS and the services it provides. Specific reference to these is detailed within relevant EFM policies and procedures.

Building and Construction Regulations: NHS Health Care Technical Memorandums (HTMs) and Health Bui8lding Notes (HBNs) are the main source of specific healthcare-related guidance for estates and facilities professionals. They provide comprehensive advice and guidance on the design, installation and operation of specialities building and engineering technolo0gy used in the delivery of healthcare.

Standing Financial Instructions: (SFIs): The Standing Financial Instructions (SFIs) detail the financial responsibilities that apply to everyone that working with the Trust – these are designed to ensure that all financial transaction are carried out in accordance with the Trust guideline, law and government policy.
Estates Return and Information Collection (ERIC):

ERIC data enables the analysis of estates and facilities information healthcare providers. It is a mandatory requirement that returns are submitted, which in turn becomes part of national statistics and can be used to indicate its performance.
BSI service standards
The EFM directorate measures itself against the following standards as an integrated service as seen in Appendix 1
ISO 9001:2015 Quality Management System (EFM – Hard and Soft Services & MEMS)

This standard is based on a number of quality management principles including a strong customer focus, the motivation and implication of top management, the process approach and continual improvement. Certification can attain significant improvements in organisational efficiency, minimising waste and errors and increasing productivity. Organizations use the standard to demonstrate the ability to consistently provide products and services that meet customer and regulatory requirements.
ISOH 45001:2018 Health & Safety Management System (EFM Hard & Soft Services)
This standard provides a framework to proactively improve employee safety, promote physical and mental health, reduce workplace risks and create safer working conditions.
ISOH 14001:2015 Environmental Management system (EFM Hard & Soft Services)

This standard provides a systematic framework for integrating environmental management practices by supporting environmental protection, pollution prevention, waste minimisation, as well as energy and materials consumption reduction.
ISO 13485:2016 Medical Devices, Quality Management System (Sterile Services)

This standard is an internationally agreed standard that sets outs the regulatory requirements for a quality management system specific to medical devices. It addressed the lifecycle of a medical device, from initial conception to production and post production, including decommission and disposal and covers aspects such as storage, distribution, installation and service and provision of associated services.
Business improvement planning
The EFM directorate is committed to seeking continual service improvements and financial efficiency in all that it delivers.

Business planning will be undertaken on an annual basis in accordance with Trust Financial Strategy and budget setting principles to ensure financial budgets are appropriate and cost pressures identified in order to manage budgets accordingly.
In addition, a cost improvement saving programme will be reviewed annually and monitored throughout the year.
In addition, service improvement plans will be reviewed annually to ensure there is a cohesive approach and work plan in place to work to, track progress and escalate delays promptly.

All efficiency and improvement plans will be formally monitored via a range of formal forums including, but not limited to, EFM Efficiency Board, Trust Corporate Efficiency Programme Board and the Financial and Performance Committee. The reporting structures can be seen in Appendices 2-3.
Principles of evaluating and reviewing

There are a range of terms used for evaluating and monitoring services standards and compliance which include assessments, audits, inspections and reviews. However, regardless of the term used, all are required to apply the Plan-Check-Act approach in order to deliver continual improvements to Estates & Facilities services. data.text: Undertaking audits
All audits must follow the following approach:
Undertaken by a competent person and appropriately trained or supervised
Following a clear set of performance indicator or objectives
Agreeing a mutually agreeable date with the auditee to undertake the audit or provide notification where multiple areas or elements are to be audited
Keeping the auditee/s informed of findings throughout the audit – particularly where non-conformances are identified
Documenting all key findings and share with auditees and appropriate interested parties, including the BDU for registering.
Record keeping

All formal audits, assessments and inspections must be documents and filed in accordance with the Procedure for Document Generation, Control and Record Management (MSEPRO19006). All formal audits and inspections should be available for retrieval and adequately protected against unauthorised alteration.

data.text: Evaluation and reporting framework
Premises Assurance Model (PAM)

PAM is an NHS contractual requirement management tool for consistent approach to evaluating NHS premises performance against a set of common indicators and is used as the overarching assessment and compliance model for EFM. The key objectives of PAM include:
Provides assurance on the premises in which NHS healthcare is delivered;
Drives premises-related performance improvements throughout the system;
Provides greater understanding of the vital role that NHS premises play in the delivery of improved clinical and social outcomes.
Being used locally by NHS organisations for Board reporting, and externally to provide assurance to Regulators and Commissioners.
PAM consists of 5 domains with PAM as follows, with a total of 46 SAQs.
PAM is monitored and reported at the following:
EFM Governance Board in a monthly basis;
Health and Safety Management Group on a quarterly basis;
Board of Directors on an annual basis.

data.text: Evaluation Category 1: Health & Safety, Fire and Business Continuity Assessments
A) Health & Safety
i) Assurance against standards/legislation compliance for ward/clinical health, safety and welfare are achieved via:
Quarterly Risk/Safety leads quarterly inspections;
Combined inspection/audit undertaken by Health and safety Advisors on an annual basis in line with agreed work plans.
ii) Assurance against standards/legislation compliance for ‘public/commons areas and engineering spaces health, safety and welfare are achieved via:
Inspection/audit undertaken by Health and safety Advisors on an annual basis in line with agreed work plans.

Internal assurance arrangements are reported to the Health and Safety Committee/Management groups. All H&S items that cannot be reasonably controlled at this level of reporting are escalated by exception to the relevant Site Governance Forum.

iii) As part of EFM assurance joint working approach, the H&S Strategy also outlines focused audit for key H&S risk areas. It is envisaged this approach may replace or be applied via annual alternation with the established H&S inspection inspection/audit assurance arrangements'.
iv) External EFM H&S assurance arrangements via British Standards Institute in line with ISO 45001.
B) Fire safety

i)The statutory fire risk assessments are undertaken through scheduled and structured audit (internal assurance) are recorded centrally and actions are pushed through the appropriate channels to make improvements to the Estate where required. These are monitored via the Fire Safety Groups and the Health and Safety Committee, with exceptions being raised through the local Risk and Compliance Groups.

ii) The Authorising Engineer for Fire (external assurance) that is referenced in the department organogram undertakes annual audits across the Group focussing on high level strategic management of fire safety and may also undertake forensic audits of areas of non-compliance where required. These are monitored via the Fire Safety Groups and the Health and Safety Committee, with exceptions being raised through the local Risk and Compliance Groups.
C) Emergency and Business Continuity

A business continuity gap analysis has been undertaken at the start of the MSE alignment process that highlighted the differences rather than gaps in compliance. A schedule of review for Business Impact Assessments, Business Continuity Plans and Action Cards is in place and is monitored and driven corporately. Business continuity exercises are scheduled with departments.
Evaluation Category 2: PLACE Assessments

a) Patient Led Assessments of the Care Environment (PLACE) is designed to assist NHS organisations assess their premises across a range of environmental aspects against common guidelines, offering a non-technical view of the buildings and non-clinical services provided across the hospital as seen from the patients' perspective. All assessment teams must consist of at least 50% patient representatives. All NHS organisations with premises that have  or more inpatient beds are required to undertake a PLACE assessment annually and submit their results via a web portal to NHSi.

b) NHSi provides a pre-determined selection of audit tools and questionnaires relating to the specific types of environment such as wards or clinics. The Trusts' final results are then scored as 6 categories which refers to actual scores achieved shown as % of maximum possible scores possible. These include: Cleanliness; Condition, Appearance and Maintenance; Privacy & Dignity; Dementia Friendly; Disability and Food.

c) The scores are not used as thresholds but rather for benchmarking purposes against other NHS organisations. They are also considered by CQC and for efficiency reports (i.e. Model Hospital) for data triangulation purposes.
Evaluation Category 3: Authorised Engineer (AE) Audits

a) Authorising Engineer (AE) Audits (external audits undertaken by third party specialists) are carried out on an annual basis and the resulting action plans and audit scores are reported and monitored at the relevant governance groups such as water safety groups, the Health and Safety Management Groups and the EFM Board.
Evaluation Category 4: Internal Audits
a) A range of internal audits are required to verify some elements standards and compliance that either self-monitored or are deemed significant to require additional evaluation.

b)These include, but are not limited to: legislation, record management, policies and procedures, records, procurement and incident management. An internal audit programme outlines each audit, which is documented all non-conformances and other relevant findings, including opportunities for improvement. The process for undertaking internal audit can be seen in the Business Development Unit Manual.
Evaluation Category : Local Service Audits
Service Leads undertake a range of local audits to self-monitor standards against identified key performance indicators which are listed in the EFM Evaluation & Assurance Framework.
Evaluation Category : External Audits

There is a wide range of external bodies that undertake audits or inspections including, but not limited to, CQC, BSI. The definition of an external agency refers to any organisation which has an advisory or regulatory role concerning the corporate or professional activities of the Trust or which has a statutory right to visit, audit or inspect the Trust's premises or activities. The process for conducting any external inspections or reviews will follow Trust Policy for the Management of External Agency Reviews, Inspections and Accreditations.
Evaluation Category 7: Management Review

The EFM Board will undertake a management review on a bi-annual basis to ensure all management systems are reviewed annually as outlined below. Both management reviews will include any actions from the previous management review
Evaluation Category : Ad-Hoc Spot Checks
Where previous audits have highlighted specifically issues that need to be closely monitored prior to post rectification, spot checks may be undertaken as and when deemed necessary.
Evaluation Category 9: User Feedback

The EFM directorate recognises the value from feedback from service users including staff, patients and visitors. Feedback is received through complaints, concerns raised via Patient Advisory Liaison Services (PALS) and through a range of surveys.
Risk management

The EFM directorate is responsible for ensuring that a process is in place to establish, implement and maintain a process for the elimination of hazards and reduction of risks through a hierarchy of controls. All risks and incidents are managed within in accordance with the Trust Risk Management Policy and Procedure and Health & Safety Policy.
Local Risk Assessment Management

EFM risks deemed manageable at local service level will be managed by local managers. Risk assessments are required to be undertaken for all EFM services and practices to ensure risks are identified (and escalated where necessary), controlled and any necessary mitigating actions put in place. These will be undertaken on an annual basis or in the event of change that may create or change hazards.
A central log of all Service EFM risks assessments will be held centrally and compliance of annual review will be reported in the monthly EFM Performance Report.
Service specific risk assessment register – maintained by BDU
H&S risk assessments register – maintained by H&S Team
Fire Safety risk assessment register – maintained by the Fire Safety Team
The BDU, H&S and Fire Safety teams will prompt managers to review local EFM risks on annually (or as appropriate should potential risk causations significantly
change).
Assurances against the risk assessments will form part of the audits and inspections as set out in section 7.
In accordance with the H&S Strategy 2020-22, it is envisaged the introduction of ‘Red book' or ‘virtual red book' managed by local H&S leads across all sites will form the basis for:
Operative access for local risks and;
Act the primary source of service level risks review action assurance against risk review prompts from H&S team.
EFM register risk

Risks deemed appropriate for EFM Risk register incorporation will be identified initially by Service/Directorate leads or at associated management group/committee level. A summary of the how risks are identifying, approved and recorded can be seen in Appendix 4
Preliminary EFM risk assurance generation will commence via the BDU or H&S Team who will discuss the risk & assist completion of risk template.

Upon agreement that risk template is completed to a satisfactory level and logged appropriately, the unapproved EFM risk will be presented to the ‘EFM Governance Board' Members for Directorate level approval. The approval form to add, change or close risks at EFM Governance Board can been seen in Appendix

Once agreed (and or amended accordingly), this risk will be presented to the Risk and Compliance Group (RCG) for approval and uploaded to DCIQ Risk Module. In the interim of the RCG being held, the risk can be uploaded as “pending approval” until such time the RCG approves it.
Likewise, where risks are deemed to reduce or be closed, the same process as above will follow.
Incident management

The Business Development Unit is notified of all EFM related incidents via DCIQ at the time of reporting – the investigation officer assigned at the time of reporting is then checked to ensure the relevant IO has been assigned and amended accordingly if not.
Any significant incidents or trends are escalated at EFM Governance Board as part of EFM Performance reporting and all incidents as part of local service accountability review meetings.
